Award.AwardTitle: Research in harmonic analysis and partial differential equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Erdogan will undertake mathematics research in the areas of harmonic analysis and partial differential equations (PDE). In harmonic analysis, Erdogan focuses on problems in Euclidean spaces centered around Lebesgue norm inequalities. One subject of on-going research are the restriction estimates for the Fourier transform. In recent years Erdogan and his Ph.D. student obtained satisfactory results in some cases. He proposes to continue his investigations on restriction estimates, and on their applications in PDE and geometric measure theory. In PDE, the focus is on the dynamical properties of dispersive PDE. One subject of on-going research is dispersive decay and smoothing estimates for the Schrodinger equation (SE). Another topic is the regularity of nonlinear dispersive PDE such as the Korteweg-de Vries (KdV) equation. Erdogan and his collaborators recently obtained smoothing bounds for KdV, and found applications to long-term behavior of the solutions. The techniques employed in this work are applicable to a wide range of PDE. Erdogan will continue his investigations in this direction. He will also work on mathematical problems on non-linear SE motivated by the numerical studies in fiber optic communication systems.


Harmonic analysis has played major roles in pure and applied sciences since Fourier's seminal work on the theory of heat diffusion, continuing on with Schrodinger's equation in quantum mechanics. This mathematics research project is partly concerned with problems coming from real-world applications. For example, the X-ray transform, an integral operator, applied to the density function of a patient's body is essentially the data obtained by magnetic resonance imaging. The dispersion managed solitons are used commercially in transatlantic fiber optic internet cables. A better understanding of the underlying mathematical structure may be useful in improving these systems. The dispersive decay and smoothing estimates have a wide range of applications in nonlinear partial differential equations modeling diverse physical phenomena. In particular, the nonlinear Schrodinger equation models the transmission of data in fiber optic communication systems, and the Korteweg-de Vries equation models surface water waves as well as ion-acoustic waves in cold plasma.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the life of this award the PI made contributions to the theory of linear and nonlinear dispersive partial differential equations. In particular, he obtained dispersive estimates for Schrodinger and wave equations, established smoothing estimates for Korteweg de Vries (KdV), Zakharov, nonlinear Schrodinger (NLS), and fractional NLS equations. Furthermore, he provided various applications of smoothing such as existense of global attractors, fractal solutions (Talbot effect), and growth bounds for the Sobolev norms. The efforts of the PI and his collaborators resulted in 14 research articles and an introductory book in this area.

 

Intellectual merit: Strichartz and other dispersive estimates for linear parial differential equations have wide range of applications in nonlinear equations, and in particular in the stability problems of solitary solutions.

Understanding smoothing properties of nonlinear equations such as the Zakharov system and NLS equation allows one to extend the results for the easier to understand linear problems to the full nonlinear equation. Growth of solutions, existence and structure of global attractors, continuity properties of solutions are among such applications.

The Talbot effect and near-linear behavior are directly motivated by problems in engineering and physics. The KdV equation, the Zakharov system, and the fractional NLS  are very well studied equations. The Zakharov system describes the propagation of Langmuir waves in an ionized plasma. KdV describes very diverse physical phenomena such as the surface water waves in shallow water, propagation of ion-acoustic waves in a cold plasma, and pressure waves in a liquid-gas bubble mixture. Fractional NLS is a basic model equation in the theory of fractional
quantum mechanics. It is also used as a model describing charge transport in bio polymers like DNA. PI's research outcomes on the regularity properties of these equations contribute to a better understanding of the long time dynamics of the solutions.

 

Broader Impact: The PI teaches and supervises graduate and undergraduate students as well as postdoctoral associates in science and engineering programs in a large public school. The expertise the students gain from PI's efforts contributes to their success as teachers, scientist and engineers in the future.

Two of PI's graduate students, F. Temur and S. Demirbas (joint with N. Tzirakis), obtained their PhD during this award. Temur is a tenure track assistant professor at Izmir Institute of Technology, Turkey, and Demirbas is a postdoc at Northeastern University.  Another student of the PI, E. Toprak,  produced two research articles.  She will graduate in two years. The PI also trained (joint with J. Tyson) a postdoctoral researchers, V. Chousionis, who is now a tenure track assistant professor at University of Connecticut.

Finally, the PI disseminated his research outcomes through seminars in multiple scientific meetings, and through publications, providing easy access to research outcomes for a wide range of audience in sciences and engineering.
